Network

The Network module provides TCP socket-based communication functionality for the distributed system.

Classes

ServerWrapper

class src.network.ServerWrapper(socket, thread, stop_flag)[source]

Bases: object

A wrapper class for managing a TCP server socket and its associated thread.

This class encapsulates the server socket, its accept thread, and a stop flag for clean shutdown. It provides methods for resource cleanup and socket operations.

Variables:

  • socket (socket.socket) – The underlying TCP server socket

  • thread (threading.Thread) – Thread handling incoming connections

  • stop_flag (threading.Event) – Event flag for signaling thread shutdown

__init__(socket, thread, stop_flag)[source]

Initialize a ServerWrapper instance.

Parameters:

  • socket (socket.socket) – TCP server socket

  • thread (threading.Thread) – Accept thread for handling connections

  • stop_flag (threading.Event) – Event flag for signaling shutdown

close()[source]

Clean up server resources.

Sets the stop flag to terminate the accept thread, waits for thread completion, and closes the server socket.

Functions

src.network.start_server(host, port, message_handler)[source]

Start a TCP server that handles incoming connections in separate threads.

Creates a TCP server socket bound to the specified host and port. For each incoming connection, spawns a new thread to handle message reception. Messages are processed using the provided message handler function.

Parameters:

  • host (str) – Host address to bind the server

  • port (int) – Port number to bind the server

  • message_handler (callable) – Function to process received messages

Returns:

A wrapper containing the server socket and management thread

Return type:

ServerWrapper

src.network.send_message(target_host, target_port, message)[source]

Send a message to a specific target machine.

Creates a TCP connection to the target host and port, sends the message, and automatically closes the connection when complete.

Parameters:

  • target_host (str) – Host address of the target machine

  • target_port (int) – Port number of the target machine

  • message (str) – Message to send

Example Usage

Starting a Server

from src.network import start_server

def message_handler(message):
    print(f"Received message: {message}")

# Start a server on localhost:8765
server = start_server("localhost", 8765, message_handler)

Sending Messages

from src.network import send_message

# Send a message to a machine
send_message("localhost", 8765, "Hello, Machine!")
